source.d90d1f32:
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import scipy as sp
from plotly import __version__
from plotly.offline import download_plotlyjs, init_notebook_mode, plot, iplot
import plotly.graph_objs as go
import seaborn as sns
import math
import colorlover as cl 

init_notebook_mode(connected=True)
source.85496fc5:
df['Q26']=np.where(df['Q26'] =='Definitely yes', 'Consider to be Data Scientist', df['Q26'])
df['Q26']=np.where(df['Q26'] =='Probably yes', 'Consider to be Data Scientist', df['Q26'])
df['Q26']=np.where(df['Q26'] =='Probably not', 'Not Consider to be Data Scientist', df['Q26'])
df['Q26']=np.where(df['Q26'] =='Definitely not', 'Not Consider to be Data Scientist', df['Q26'])

df['Q26'] = df['Q26'].copy()
source.9ee25c08:
dcs = df[df['Q26']=='Consider to be Data Scientist']
dncs = df[df['Q26']=='Not Consider to be Data Scientist']
dm = df[df['Q26']=='Maybe']
source.f0646b7d:
print ("""2018 Kaggle ML & DS Survey received """,len(df),"""respondents from 147 countries and territories.\n
We divided into three categories based on Question 26 “Do you consider yourself to be a data scientist?”: \n
1. Consider to be data scientist – definitely yes and probably yes""",np.round(len(dcs)*100/len(df),2),"""%""", """
2. Neutral – maybe""",np.round(len(dm)*100/len(df),2),"""%""","""
3. Not consider to be data scientist – definitely no and probably no""",np.round(len(dncs)*100/len(df),2),"""%\n
In the explanation below, we will focus on two categories which are : \n
‘Consider to be data scientist’ and ‘Not consider to be data scientist’.""")
source.37ba251f:
# for multiple
array_cds = ['Consider to be Data Scientist']
cds = df.loc[df['Q26'].isin(array_cds)]
source.a3e79441:
# for multiple
array_ncds = ['Not Consider to be Data Scientist']
ncds = df.loc[df['Q26'].isin(array_ncds)]
source.38a5cc46:
Q3 = pd.DataFrame(pd.value_counts(df.Q3))
data_Q3 = [ dict(
        type = 'choropleth',
        colorscale = [[0.0, 'rgb(0,153,153)'],[1.0, 'rgb(128,255,255)']],
        locations = Q3.index,
        locationmode = 'country names',
        z = np.round(Q3['Q3'].values*100/len(df),2),
        text = Q3.index,
        autocolorscale = False,
        reversescale = True,
        marker = dict(
            line = dict (
                color = 'rgb(0,51,51)',
                width = 0.5
            ) ),
        colorbar = dict(
            autotick = False,
            ticksuffix = '%',
            title = 'Respondent Countries (%)'),
      ) ]

layout_Q3 = dict(
    title = 'Kaggle Survey (2018) - Country',
    geo = dict(
        showframe = False,
        showcoastlines = False,
        projection = dict(
            type = 'Mercator'
        )
    ),
    autosize=True
)

fig_Q3 = dict(data=data_Q3, layout=layout_Q3)
iplot(fig_Q3, validate=False)
source.e4974ba9:
Q3_consider = df.groupby("Q3")["Q26"].apply(lambda x: (x=="Consider to be Data Scientist").sum()).reset_index(name="QC_Q3")
Q3_notconsider = df.groupby("Q3")["Q26"].apply(lambda x: (x=="Not Consider to be Data Scientist").sum()).reset_index(name="QNC_Q3")

source.83fb86f0:

ncds_q11 = get_count_question_ncds('Q11')
cds_q11 = cds_q11.rename(columns={'count': 'QC_Q11'})
ncds_q11 = ncds_q11.rename(columns={'count': 'QNC_Q11'})

Q11_merge.sort_values("QC_Q11",ascending=False,inplace=True)

Q14_merge.sort_values("QC_Q14",ascending=False,inplace=True)

source.da461e57: The bar chart illustrates experience in current role of respondents which divided into CDS & NCDS. It can be seen that 74.53% of the respondent has experience less than 5 years in current role based on CDS category. We can also see from the chart that experience in current role of respondent doesn’t affect respondent’s consideration to be data scientist.
source.77fc46de:
Based on the visualisation, there are several factors that affect someone’s consideration to be Data Scientist, such as:
1.	Education background -> respondents that have degree such as bachelor, master, doctoral and professional.
2.	Role responsibility -> respondents who work with data.
3.	Time spent coding -> respondents that use their time more than 25% to code.
4.	Coding experience -> respondents that have coding experience more than 1 year.
5.	Analytics tools -> respondents who use local or hosted development environments, advanced statistical software, cloud-based data software and APIs, business intelligence software.

Answering the question 'Is Data Science For Me?', based on the data above, we can say that everyone can be Data Scientist, do not worry about the demographic and education matters, as long as you want to learn about Data Science, we believe that you can be Data Scientist someday. and here are some tips for newcomers:
1. For Programming Language, you can start using Python or R or SQL
2. For IDE, you can start using Jupyter/IPython or RStudio
3. For Hosted Notebook, you can start using Kaggle Kernels, it is free and good if you want to execute code without installing anything to keep on working on your data or JupyterHub/Binder 
4. For Public Dataset, you can start finding public dataset from dataset aggregator/platform like Socrata or Kaggle Public Dataset
5. For Data Visual Library, you can start using Matplotlib, ggplot2, and Seaborn
6. For Online Course Platform, you can find course about data scientist in Coursera, DataCamp, Udemy and etc

Thank you for your time to read our story about Kaggle’s Survey 2018. Hopefully it is useful for you. We just kick start our journey to become data scientist and would appreciate hearing your thoughts :)
source.be20dbd8: On this occasion, we would like to grasp which factors affect people’s consideration to be Data Scientist or not with the intention of giving insight for newcomers.
source.eecd14c3: The bar chart illustrates responsibility of respondent’s current role which divided into CDS & NCDS. It can be seen that Analyse and understand data (26.30%), Build prototypes to explore applying machine learning (21.83%), Build and/or run a machine learning service (17.22%) are top 3 responsibility of respondent’s current role based on CDS category. We can also see from the chart that respondent’s current role affects respondent’s consideration to be data scientist. People who work with data, tend to consider themselves to be Data Scientist.
source.140bf353: The bar chart illustrates experience in writing code to analyse data of respondents which divided into CDS & NCDS. It can be seen that 71.57% of respondents have experience up to 5 years writing code to analyse data based on CDS category. We can also see from the chart that experience in writing code to analyse data affects respondent’s consideration to be data scientist. People who have experience more than 1 year, tend to consider themselves to be Data Scientist.
source.24e01665: The map chart illustrates distribution of respondents from 147 countries and territories. It can be seen that United States of America (19.77%), India (18.51%), China (6.89%), Russia (3.68%), and Brazil (3.08%) are top 5 respondent countries.
source.d91888f2: The bar chart illustrates most commonly used programming language which divided into CDS & NCDS. It can be seen that Python (60.48%), R (15.98%) and SQL (6.88%) are top 3 languages based on CDS category. We can also see from the chart that most commonly used programming language doesn’t affect respondent’s consideration to be data scientist.
source.ac8291e2: The bar chart illustrates industry of respondent’s current employer which divided into CDS & NCDS. It can be seen that Computers/Technology (27.62%), Student (15.41%), Academics/Education (12.66%), Accounting/Finance (7.68%), Online Service/Internet-based Service (4.26%) are top 5 industry of respondent’s current employer based on CDS category. We can also see from the chart that industry doesn’t affect respondent’s consideration to be data scientist.
source.c6637ff3: The bar chart illustrates most common online course which divided into CDS & NCDS. It can be seen that Coursera (41.02%), DataCamp (12.25%) and Udemy (11.06%) are top 3 common online course based on CDS category. Coursera provides one of the longest-established online data science education, even though it is not completely free, but this is waived for students who don’t have financial resources available (Forbes, 2017). From the chart we can also see that most common online course doesn’t affect respondent’s consideration to be data scientist.
source.0464b9fc: From respondent’s undergraduate major, it can be seen that Computer Science (38.30%), Mathematics or Statistics (16.14%), Engineering (non-computer focused) (15.92%), A Business discipline (7.20%), and Physics or Astronomy (6.15%) are top 5 respondent’s undergraduate major. We can also see from the chart that undergraduate major doesn’t affect respondent’s consideration to be data scientist.
source.2d9ba4be: The bar chart illustrates Public Dataset Provider which divided into CDS & NCDS. It can be seen that Dataset aggregator/platform (16.99%), Google Search (14.62%) and GitHub (13.25%) are top 3 common Public Dataset Provider based on CDS category. From the chart we can also see that Public Dataset Provider doesn’t affect respondent’s consideration to be data scientist.
source.68690497: The bar chart illustrates education background of respondents which divided into CDS & NCDS. It can be seen that Master’s Degree (49.60%), Bachelor’s Degree (24.14%) and Doctoral Degree (19.35%) are top 3 respondent’s education background based on CDS category. There is significant pattern that we can see from the chart. Respondents that have degree such as Bachelor, Master, Doctoral, Professional tend to consider to be data scientist.
source.e60ebf5a: The bar chart illustrates age of respondents which divided into CDS & NCDS. It can be seen that 25-29, 22-24 and 30-34 are top 3 respondent’s age based on CDS category. There is no significant pattern that distinguishes CDS and NCDS category when we look at respondent’s gender.
source.c10a54d3: The bar chart illustrates IDE usage which divided into CDS & NCDS. It can be seen that Jupyter/IPython (18.75%), RStudio (11.93%), and Notepad++ (9.70%) are top 3 IDE based on CDS category. Jupyter/IPython is a free, open-source, interactive web tool which can be used to combine software code, computational output, explanatory text and multimedia resources in single document. It can also speak dozens of programming language that makes it popular over the past couple years (Nature, 2018). From the chart we can also see that IDE usage doesn’t affect respondent’s consideration to be data scientist.
source.6e246550: Based on Forbes (2017), to become data scientist, we have to learn Python, R and SQL as the foundation of our core competency because it will get our foot into the door of the majority of open position in the field. Familiarity with other skill sets listed will only add our ability to secure the job we want and earn top-range salary.
source.e97cdcf6: The bar chart illustrates current role of respondents which divided into CDS & NCDS. It can be seen that Data Scientist (32.90%), Student (15.83%), Software Engineer (9.04%), Data Analyst (8.23%), Research Scientist (6.34%) are top 5 respondent’s role based on CDS category. We can also see from the chart that current roles doesn’t affect respondent’s consideration to be data scientist.
source.14af89a8: The bar chart illustrates Hosted Notebooks usage which divided into CDS & NCDS. It can be seen that Kaggle Kernels (24.33%), JupyterHub/Binder (19.64%), Google Colab (14.30%) are top 3 hosted notebooks based on CDS category. Kaggle Kernels allows us to execute code without installing R or Python, so we do not have to install anything to keep on working on our data (medium, 2018). From the chart we can also see that Hosted Notebooks usage doesn’t affect respondent’s consideration to be data scientist.
source.301053c6: The bar chart illustrates Big Data and Analytics Products which divided into CDS & NCDS. It can be seen that Google BigQuery (9.13%), AWS Redshift (7.87%), Databricks (7.24%) are top 3 Big Data and Analytics Products based on CDS category. From the chart we can also see that Big Data and Analytics Products usage doesn’t affect respondent’s consideration to be data scientist.
source.9458f6ea: Charts below will help newcomers to choose tools or product to kickstart their journey as data scientist.
source.e5f2f78a: The bar chart illustrates gender of respondents which divided into CDS & NCDS. It can be seen that male is dominant (the ratio is 5:1) based on CDS category. There is no significant pattern that distinguishes CDS and NCDS category when we look at respondent’s gender.
source.caccacfd: The bar chart illustrates recommended language to learn first which divided into CDS & NCDS. It can be seen that Python (75.95%), R (13.59%) and SQL (4.58%) are top 3 languages based on CDS category. We can also see from the chart that recommended language to learn first doesn’t affect respondent’s consideration to be data scientist.
source.645451e6: The bar chart illustrates Cloud Computing Service which divided into CDS & NCDS. It can be seen that Amazon Web Services (31.37%), Google Cloud Platform (19.84%), Microsoft Azure (15.65%) are top 3 Cloud Computing Service based on CDS category. From the chart we can also see that Cloud Computing Service doesn’t affect respondent’s consideration to be data scientist.
source.06f224ca: The bar chart illustrates most commonly used data visualization library which divided into CDS & NCDS. It can be seen that Matplotlib (53.89%), ggplot2 (23.79%) and Seaborn (11.75%) are top 3 commonly used data visualisation library based on CDS category. From the chart we can also see that most commonly used data visualization library doesn’t affect respondent’s consideration to be data scientist.
source.b33c9072: We are in the midst of the Fourth Industrial Revolution (FIR) and its promises improves productivity, flexibility, and efficiency in all aspects of our lives. The ability to utilise and analyse data is going to be one of the biggest drivers to survive in the disruptive era. This attracts attention from many parties especially Kaggle that has conducted Kaggle’s second annual Machine Learning (ML) and Data Science (DS) Survey to understand the global, diverse, and dynamic nature of data science and machine learning industry.
source.21c8c892: The bar chart illustrates time spent coding of respondents which divided into CDS & NCDS. It can be seen that 79.91% of respondents use 25% to 99% of their time to code based on CDS category. We can also see from the chart that time spent coding affects respondent’s consideration to be data scientist. People who use their time more than 25% to code, tend to consider themselves to be Data Scientist.
source.494a1276: The bar chart illustrates distribution of respondents which divided into CDS & NCDS. It can be seen that United States of America (21.04%), India (17.51%), China (6.18%), Russia (4.66%), Germany (3.25%) are top 5 respondent countries based on CDS category. There is no significant pattern that distinguishes CDS and NCDS category when we look at respondent countries.
source.e68864f0: The bar chart illustrates most common analytics tools which divided into CDS & NCDS. It can be seen that local or hosted development environments (58.69%), basic statistical software (12.87%), advance statistical software (8.14%) are top 3 common analytics tools based on CDS category. From the chart we can also see that people who use basic statistical software, tend not to consider themselves to be Data Scientist.
